questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is told about the benefits and complications of hysterectomy and she agrees to the procedure. What kind of consent is this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Informed consent

 

Informed consent is obtained when a patient is provided with comprehensive information about a medical procedure, including its benefits, risks, and possible complications, and then agrees to undergo the procedure. This ensures that the patient's decision is based on an understanding of all relevant information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Implied consent: Implied consent is assumed when a patient visits a healthcare provider for a basic examination. It does not apply to invasive procedures like surgery.

 

Option C. Opt out: Opt-out consent is used when consent is presumed unless the individual actively declines. This is not applicable in the context of medical procedures requiring explicit consent.

 

Option D. Passive consent: Passive consent typically refers to situations where consent is inferred from a lack of objection. This is not applicable in medical contexts where explicit, informed consent is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consent can be classified in two ways:

 

1. Based on how the consent is given

 

 

2. Based on how much information provided:

questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022)

 

  1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
  2. Baby on artificial feeds
  3. Baby of working mother/single parent
  4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
  5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Among the given options, babies on artificial feeds and babies of working/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

 

 

It is important to identify children at risk and give special intensive care. This is done because these children contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

choices.text: Annular hymen

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate hymen: Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate hymen: Tiny opening
    • Annular hymen: Oval central opening
    • Septate hymen: Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate hymen: Boat-like opening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imperforate hymen: An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.

 

Option B. Semilunar hymen: A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Annular hymen: An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.

 

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

 

The patient presents with signs of paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, indicated by the ingestion of a high dose, deranged liver function tests (LFTs), and oliguria. Paracetamol overdose can lead to severe hepatotoxicity and acute liver failure.

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity. It works by replenishing glutathione stores, enhancing non-toxic metabolism of paracetamol, and reducing the formation of harmful metabolites. Early administration of N-acetylcysteine significantly reduces the risk of liver damage and improves outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is used in the management of shock to improve renal perfusion and cardiac output. It is not indicated in the treatment of paracetamol toxicity and does not address the underlying hepatic damage.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in the treatment of certain cholestatic liver diseases to improve bile flow. It does not play a role in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload conditions such as heart failure or renal failure. It does not address the hepatotoxicity caused by paracetamol overdose and is not part of the standard treatment protocol for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day. Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools. If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.

 

Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents. Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.

 

Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea. Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications. Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline

 

The patient's symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions are suggestive of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that is used in the management of Parkinson's disease. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine, thereby increasing its availability in the brain and helping to alleviate symptoms like rigidity and tremors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it can be used in Parkinson's disease patients who experience psychosis, it is not a first-line treatment for the primary motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B. Donepezil: Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It enhances cholinergic function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain. It is not typically used for treating Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic and can actually worsen Parkinson's disease symptoms. It blocks dopamine receptors, which could exacerbate the dopamine deficiency characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that increases dopamine availability in the brain and is used to manage the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as rigidity and tremors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-rebreathing mask

 

The oxygen delivery device shown in the image above is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM).

 

Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM):

  • The non-rebreathing mask provides high concentrations of oxygen. It features a reservoir bag attached to it, which helps in providing a high flow of oxygen.
  • The mask has one-way valves that prevent exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring that only oxygen is inhaled.
  • The maximum FiO2 given by an NRBM is approximately 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: A Venturi mask is designed to deliver a precise oxygen concentration. It has interchangeable valves that regulate the amount of oxygen and ambient air mix, providing specific FiO2 levels. It is typically used when controlled oxygen therapy is required.

 

 

 

Option B. Hudson mask: The Hudson mask, also known as a simple face mask, delivers oxygen concentrations ranging from 40% to 60%. It does not have a reservoir bag and is less precise in delivering a specific oxygen concentration compared to the Venturi mask.

 

 

Option C. Nebulizer mask: A nebulizer mask is used to deliver aerosolized medications (such as bronchodilators) to patients. It is attached to a nebulizer machine, which converts liquid medication into a fine mist for inhalation. This mask is not primarily used for oxygen delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is an oxygen delivery device that provides high concentrations of oxygen, up to approximately 80%, and is characterized by a reservoir bag and one-way valves to ensure the inhalation of high-purity oxygen.

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism. Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic syndrome

 

  • The skin lesion shown in the image of axilla with velvety textured skin is indicative of Acanthosis nigricans. In this case, the patient is most likely suffering from Metabolic syndrome based on the diagnosis.

 

Acanthosis nigricans

  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism primarily manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia, alopecia and dry skin. It doesn't typically lead to velvety skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Addison’s disease:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, leads to symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation. However, the hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's is more diffuse and not restricted to velvety changes in the axilla.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

  • This condition primarily results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. Symptoms include kidney stones, bone pain, and fatigue. Skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans are not a typical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References –

Harrisons principle s of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 390, 2933,2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3086, 3150, 3151, 3154, 3155, 3156, 3173, 3175

Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2022 Page no 1157

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 147, Page no 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 391

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unstable Angina

 

The patient's presentation includes chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin (NTG), stable vitals, and normal cardiac enzymes. The provided ECG is normal, showing no signs of ST elevation or ischemic changes such as ST depression or T wave inversion.

 

Unstable Angina involves chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion, and normal cardiac enzymes. The patient has multiple risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, aortic sclerosis), and the fact that his chest pain did not respond to NTG and his enzymes are normal strongly suggests unstable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. STEMI: STEMI is characterized by ST elevation on ECG and elevated cardiac enzymes indicating myocardial necrosis. This patient's ECG shows no ST elevation, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, making STEMI unlikely.

 

Option B. NSTEMI: NSTEMI would present with elevated cardiac enzymes due to myocardial damage, despite the absence of ST elevation. This patient’s normal enzyme levels exclude NSTEMI.

 

Option C. Stable Angina: Stable angina presents with chest pain that is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient’s chest pain persisted despite taking NTG, indicating that stable angina is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion, does not respond to nitroglycerin, and is associated with normal cardiac enzyme levels.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus: Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)

 

 

Option C. Uterine didelphys: Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever

 

 

Option D. Unicornuate uterus: Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.

 

Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Identify the condition and the instrument:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

 

RULE OF IMMOBILISATION

 

  • Immobilise one joint above and 1 joint below the main target
  • Femur fracture: Fixation at hip joint and knee joint
  • Tibia fracture: Fixation at knee joint and ankle joint
  • Periarticular Knee fracture: Fixation at hip joint and ankle joint
  • Peri- and intra-articular fractures about the knee are frequently managed with joint-spanning external fixation before definitive treatment.
  • With a systematic approach, a near-anatomic reduction with respect to length, alignment, and rotation can be obtained.

 

KNEE SPANNING EXTERNAL FIXATOR

 

  • A joint-bridging external fixator is fixed to the femur and the tibia while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged).
  • Provisional reduction is achieved with distraction.
  • When external fixation is used to bridge the knee joint, it is always only for temporary fixation. Prolonged immobilization will lead to difficulties with knee mobility.
  • It is rapidly applied without need for intraoperative x-rays and can be adjusted later.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia fracture, Ilizarov fixator. The most stable external fixation for distal tibial fractures is usually composed by:

 

  • One fully circular ring with tensioned wires attached to the distal tibial articular segment
  • Two proximal fully circular rings to provide stable anchorage for the distal ring
  • An extension for the foot and ankle, and particularly for intraarticular fractures
  • 3-4 connecting rods between each ring

 

The proximal rings can be anchored with Schanz screws or tensioned wires. Wires are usually used in cancellous bone. Wires attached to a circular ring are typically tensioned at 100 to 130 kg-force.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

A spanning external fixator is used for stabilization of open and closed fractures, mainly intraarticular fractures of the lower extremity, around the knee and ankle joints.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: Where will be the level of the uterus 48 hours after delivery?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5 cm below umbilicus

 

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus
  • it remains at level of umbilicus for 24 hours. Following this, it involutes
  • It involutes 1.25 cm/ day form the 2nd day onwards
  • So, after 48 hours (2 days) post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2.5 cm breadth below the umbilicus
  • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days
  • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks
  • alternatively, it reduces by 1 finger breadth / day from 2nd day post partum, till it becomes pelvic organ by 10-14 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterus will be 2.5 cm below umbilicus on the second-day post-delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 169, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

choices.text: Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
    • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
    • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
    • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.

 

Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

 

Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm.
