Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: Identify the histological structure shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pancreatic islet cells

 

  • The pancreas has two main parts: the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.
  • The endocrine part of the pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans, which are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and numerous fenestrated capillaries.
  • Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to the presence of less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The image provided depicts the histology of the pancreas.

 

 

Pancreatic Islet Cells (Islets of Langerhans): Scattered throughout the pancreas, these islets are endocrine clusters differing from the surrounding exocrine pancreatic tissue.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Alpha Cells: Produce glucagon which increases blood glucose levels.
  • Beta Cells: The most common islet cell, producing insulin which decreases blood glucose levels.
  • Delta Cells: Produce somatostatin, which regulates the other islet cells.
  • Gamma Cells (PP or F cells): Produce pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates some of the pancreatic exocrine and endocrine functions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures found throughout the lymphatic system.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: A dense connective tissue covering.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule that divide the node into compartments.
  • Cortex: Contains densely packed lymphocytes and has follicles with germinal centers.
  • Medulla: Central part containing medullary cords (lymphatic tissue) and medullary sinuses filled with lymph.
  • Hilum: The area where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit and where the efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node.

 

Option B. Glomerulus: A tuft of capillaries situated within Bowman's capsule in the nephron of the kidney.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Endothelial Cells: These line the inner surface of the capillaries.
  • Basement Membrane: Lies between the endothelial cells and the podocytes, playing a critical role in filtering the blood.
  • Podocytes: These are specialized epithelial cells that cover the outer surfaces of the glomerular capillaries. Their foot processes interdigitate and form filtration slits.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillary loops and provide structural support and phagocytic functions.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that filters blood and is involved in immune reactions.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: Dense connective tissue with smooth muscle cells.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule containing blood vessels.
  • White Pulp: Lymphatic tissue arranged around arterioles (central arteries). It's involved in immune responses.
  • Red Pulp: Consists of splenic cords (reticular connective tissue with many blood-filled sinuses). It filters the blood of antigens, microorganisms, and defective or worn-out red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient’s symptoms of unilateral headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia are classic indicators of a migraine. Migraine is a common condition in young females and can be associated with other symptoms such as primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

For the acute management of migraines:

 

  • Mild to moderate attacks – Paracetamol or NSAIDs like Ketorolac.
  • Moderate to severe attacks - Triptans are the drugs of choice. Other group of drugs are Ditans/ Gepants
    • Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan a commonly used triptan, is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist which effectively alleviates migraine symptoms by causing vasoconstriction of the dilated blood vessels thought to be responsible for migraine pain. This action helps to reduce the headache and associated symptoms rapidly. - All of these drugs are contraindicated in the setting of pregnancy except paracetamol. Triptans are unsafe in vascular conditions
    • Ditans (Ex. Lasmiditan) are 5-HT1F receptor agonists. Unlike triptans, they do not cause vasoconstriction, making them safer for patients with vascular conditions such as coronary artery disease or peripheral arterial disease.
    • Gepents are CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) antagonists or blocker. Gepents, including rimegepant, atogepant, ubrogepant, and zabigipant, are effective in migraine management. These are oral medications and do not cause vasoconstriction, which also makes them suitable for patients with certain vascular conditions.

 

Note - Dopamine Receptor Blockers: Prochlorperazine is mentioned as an example of this class. While not the focus of the discussion, dopamine receptor blockers are noted as effective in managing migraines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily for the prophylactic (preventive) treatment of migraines, not for acute management. It helps in reducing the frequency of migraine attacks but does not relieve symptoms once an attack has started.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used for the prophylaxis of migraines. It is effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraine attacks over time but is not used for immediate relief during an acute migraine episode.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is an anticonvulsant medication also used for the prophylactic treatment of migraines. Similar to propranolol, it helps prevent migraines but is not effective in treating acute migraine symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the drug of choice for the acute management of moderate to severe migraine attacks due to its vasoconstrictive properties and effectiveness in rapidly alleviating migraine symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’. It is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

Dermal Vascular Necrosis

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.

  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.

  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.

  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.

  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.

  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.

  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.

  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis. However, heparin can cause other complications such as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is generally associated with a different profile of side effects, including bleeding.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is associated with a different side effect profile, mainly related to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis.
  • Usually occurs after penetrative trauma or intraocular surgery.
  • Both eyes develop panuveitis: the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye).
  • Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.
  • The most accepted theory is the allergic theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye.
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury.
  • Earliest symptoms in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    •  Photophobia
  • Earliest sign in uninjured eye: Retrolental flare.
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation (not evisceration) of an injured eye in order to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.

 

   

 

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) and sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) are bilateral, autoimmune granulomatous intraocular inflammatory conditions with nearly identical findings on ophthalmic exam. Both can reveal serous retinal detachments, optic disc edema, vitritis, and Dalen-Fuchs nodules, but they differ in key facets such as a history of penetrating ocular injury in SO and greater systemic associations in VKH. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis involves inflammation limited to the anterior part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and does not typically follow the pattern seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis, which affects the entire uveal tract.

 

Option B. Pars planitis: Pars planitis is a form of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the peripheral retina and pars plana. It does not encompass the entire uveal tract as in panuveitis.

 

Option D. Chronic anterior uveitis: Chronic anterior uveitis is a long-standing inflammation of the anterior uvea, typically affecting only the iris and ciliary body, not the entire uveal tract as seen in panuveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bladder exstrophy

 

The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

 

Ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. Clinical features of this condition include separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis, epispadias, and genital defects such as bifid clitoris in females and broad and short penis with bilateral inguinal hernia in males.

 

Management of bladder exstrophy involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. The first step is closure of the abdominal and bladder wall within the first year of life. This procedure may require an iliac osteotomy to relieve tension on the bladder and facilitate wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects may be performed. Alternatively, urinary diversion can be carried out by creating ureterosigmoid anastomosis, an ileal or colonic conduit, or continent urinary diversion.

 

Long-term complications of bladder exstrophy include stricture at the site of the anastomosis leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and infection, hyperchloremic acidosis, and an increased (20-fold) risk of tumor formation such as adenoma and adenocarcinoma at the site of a ureteroscopic anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: The abdominal contents are out and are covered in a sac. It is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect. It occurs due to the failure of the physiological umbilical hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels and chromosomal abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: It is a congenital anomaly that occurs during fetal development. The vitelline duct is a structure that connects the developing embryo to the yolk sac. In normal development, the vitelline duct is supposed to disappear by the time the fetus is born. However, in some cases, the duct persists and can lead to various complications.

 

Option D. gastrochisis: in this condition, the abdominal contents are out and are NOT covered in a sac.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. The management involves staged surgical reconstruction, and complications include strictures, hyperchloremic acidosis, and increased risk of tumors.

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of the device shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trophoblastic disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a copper-containing IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device).
  • ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device are:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis/ Puerperal sepsis/ Current Pelvic inflammatory/ disease, Genital Tuberculosis
    • Cancers: Endometrial cancer, Cervical cancer, Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity, Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menstruation: Intra-uterine device can be inserted even during periods although preferably it should be inserted post-menstrual

 

Option C. Immediately after delivery: This is called as Post placental IUCD insertion (within 10 mins of placental delivery)

 

Option D. Ruptured condom during intercourse: Following a ruptured condom, CUT can be inserted as an emergency contraception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophoblastic disease is an ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deferoxamine

 

Iron overdose, particularly with ferrous sulfate tablets, can lead to severe toxicity. Ingesting more than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron is considered potentially lethal. Acute iron poisoning presents with gastrointestinal symptoms initially and can progress to metabolic acidosis, shock, and multi-organ failure.

 

The presence of acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis is an important indicator of severe iron toxicity and an indication for the administration of an antidote. The appropriate antidote for acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine. Deferoxamine chelates free iron, forming a water-soluble complex that is excreted in the urine, thereby reducing iron's toxic effects on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is not effective in cases of iron poisoning. It does not adsorb metals like iron and can be harmful in certain situations like heavy metal poisoning, alcohols, petroleum products, and caustic substances.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Dimercaprol is used for chelation therapy in heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, mercury, gold) but is not effective for iron poisoning.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is another chelating agent, typically used for conditions such as Wilson's disease (copper overload) and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective in treating iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute iron intoxication with signs of toxicity such as acidosis, the antidote of choice is deferoxamine. Activated charcoal is not effective in iron poisoning and should not be used.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

choices.text: 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA
1400 for mother and 600 for ASHA
600 for mother and 400 for ASHA
400 for mother and 600 for ASHA

questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

 

Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive scheme, pregnant women who deliver in healthcare facilities are provided financial assistance. The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

 

Madhya Pradesh is categorized as a Low Performing State (LPS), the incentives are as follows:

 

  • Mother's Package: ₹1000
  • ASHA's Package: ₹400

 

Educational Objective:  

 

 

(LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)

 

(LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: What is the indication of this procedure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratoconus

 

The given image shows the placement of Intacs, which is done for keratoconus.

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea.
  • Pathognomonic features include central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea.
  • Defective vision, progressive myopia, and irregular astigmatism are common clinical features.
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present.
  • Clinical signs: 
    1. Scissor reflex (yawning reflex) on retinoscopy is the earliest sign.
    2. Oil droplet reflex is seen with distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
    3. Fleischer’s ring (Epithelial iron deposits) and Vogt lines (Oblique stromal striae) (Image given below) are seen on slit lamp examination.
      Note: Kayser –fleischer ring is due to deposition of the copper and is seen in Wilson disease and chalcosis.
    4. Rizzuti's sign, a bright reflection from the nasal area of the limbus when light is directed to the limbus temporal area.
    5. Munson’s sign (localized bulging of the lower lid on looking down) is positive in keratoconus. (Image given below)
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Vogt’s line:

 

Vogt’s triad

 

Occurs centrally in a patient with keratoconus

  • Vertical stromal/ Descemet’s membrane lines.
  • Stress lines due to stretching and thinning.
  • Disappear with globe pressure.

 

 

  • The earliest way to detect any curvature disease of the cornea including keratoconus is topography (mapping of the point-to-point thickness of the cornea).
  • The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry.
  • Treatment: Declining visual acuity may not be corrected by glasses due to irregular astigmatism.
    1. In early cases:
      • Contact lenses (rigid gas permeable)
      • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments (flatten the cornea)
    2. In later stages: Penetrating keratoplasty may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's limbal girdle: Vogt's limbal girdle is a benign, age-related condition characterized by white, chalky deposits at the limbus. It is not treated with Intacs.

 

Option C. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a condition characterized by a generalized thinning and globular protrusion of the entire cornea. It is not typically treated with Intacs.

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic, often progressive, eye disorders in which abnormal material accumulates in the cornea. Treatment varies and does not typically involve Intacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The placement of Intacs is an indicated treatment for keratoconus, a condition characterized by the thinning and protrusion of the cornea leading to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with multiple injuries, which included a femur fracture as well. He developed confusion, dyspnea, and a rash over his body. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

 

  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

  • The diagnosis is considered usually after 48 hours. 

 

Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours think of it!

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. 

  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).

    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:

      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea

      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation

      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder

 

  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:

    • Fracture stabilization

    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:

      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)

      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)

  • Offset its effect by:

    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)

    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release

    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.

  • Treatment:

    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.

    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.

    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism. An air embolism occurs when air is admitted into the vascular system. It can occur iatrogenically via interventional procedures but has also been described as a complication from a blunt and penetrating trauma. The most important diagnostic criterion is the patient's history. The procedures that carry the greatest risk of air embolism are craniotomy in the sitting position, cesarean section, hip replacement, and cardiopulmonary bypass. If the patient is conscious, chest pain, dyspnea, headache, and confusion can all be symptoms. If the embolus is severe, cardiac ischemia, arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest can ensue. 

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism. Many PEs are likely undiagnosed. Most PEs originate as venous thromboembolisms (VTEs) in the lower extremities or pelvic veins. Less frequently, upper extremity thromboembolic events lead to PE. Major risk factors for thromboembolic events include recent immobilization, MI, CVA, surgery, and recent trauma. PE may be asymptomatic or present with sudden death. Characteristic signs and symptoms such as tachycardia, dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, and shock are non-specific. 

 

Option D. DIC. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a hypercoagulable state that can lead to both microvascular and macrovascular clotting and compromised blood flow, ultimately resulting in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. It typically occurs as an acute complication in patients with underlying life-threatening illnesses such as severe sepsis, hematologic malignancies, severe trauma, or placental abruption. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with fracture of femur, complaint of breathlessness after 48 hours, is highly suggestive of fat embolism.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rd decade

 

The clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Death in DMD occurs in the late teens and 20s (3rd decade).

 

 

Gower sign:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Previous history of viral prodrome: This option is not correct. DMD is a genetic disorder and does not typically have a history of a viral prodrome.

 

Option C. It is a mitochondrial storage disorder: This option is incorrect. DMD is not a mitochondrial storage disorder; it is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene.

 

Option D. Early treatment has excellent prognosis: While early treatment with corticosteroids can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression, DMD remains a progressive and fatal disease with current treatments. Thus, early treatment does not lead to an "excellent" prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV 18

 

Explanation:

 

  • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection.
  • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11). These types, referred to as low-risk, have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

 

Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact, although non-sexual transmission is also possible.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.

 

IMIQUIMOD:

 

  • Imiquimod cream uses:
    • Actinic keratoses
    • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
    • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
       
  • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A HPV 2:

  • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet, not with anogenital warts or cancer.

 

Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11:

  • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
