  • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.

 

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.55

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 198

Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition 156, 157, 486

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 650

 

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Shivering

 

Explanation:

 

In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset to a higher temperature, hence the body uses methods like shivering to increase the temperature.

 

 

 

Fig: Effects changing the set-point of the hypothalamic temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sweating

 

  • Stage W: Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage.
  • Stage Y: Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin

 

  • Stage W: There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss.
  • Stage Y: Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis

 

  • Stage W: There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat.
  • Stage Y: As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEMPERATURE REGULATION -

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

 

Explanation:

 

The choice of dopamine agonist therapy for hyperprolactinemia in patients desiring fertility remains somewhat controversial. Advanced textbooks such as "Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility" clearly highlight that cabergoline has greater potency, fewer side effects, better tolerability, and convenient dosing compared to bromocriptine, leading to its general preference for prolactinoma treatment.

 

However, Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st Edition) explicitly mentions:

 

“Because cabergoline is long-acting with a high D₂-receptor affinity, it is not recommended for use in women when fertility is desired.”

 

Considering the context of Indian postgraduate entrance examinations, it is advisable to adhere to Harrison's recommendations. Therefore, although cabergoline is generally considered superior, bromocriptine is the safer and recommended answer for this specific examination scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cabergoline: Although generally preferred for routine prolactinoma management, it is explicitly not recommended during conception planning as per Harrison’s.

 

Option C. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog indicated exclusively for GH-secreting tumors, not prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist used specifically in acromegaly, with no role in prolactinoma or fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian PG entrance examinations, bromocriptine remains the recommended first-line treatment in women with microprolactinoma who desire fertility, despite cabergoline’s clinical advantages, based on guidelines explicitly mentioned in Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence 

 

The incident described in the scenario will be tried under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence refers to a disregard for the safety of others that is so gross or extreme that it constitutes a criminal act.

 

Even in emergency, the surgeon should not have performed operation while under the influence of alcohol.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence: In this there is no specific and clear violation of law. Simple absence of care and skill. The trial is conducted in a civil court and typically results in fine as punishment. The negligence described in the scenario is too gross to be considered merely civil negligence.

 

Option C. Therapeutic Misadventure (Medical Maloccurence): Individual is injured or died due to some unintentional Act by a doctor/hospital and is not related to the quality of care provided. It is an unforeseen accident due to individual biological variations. Here no one is negligent.

 

Option D. Dichotomy or Fee Splitting or Sharing: Giving of a commission  by  one  doctor  to  another  for  referring, recommending, or procuring any patients for medical, surgical or other treatment. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by State Medical Council. The punishment can be:

 

  • Warning
  • Penal erasure (professional death sentence).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

 

Child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months with  air fluid levels on otoscopy is suggestive of serous otitis media.

 

Aetiology

 

  1. Eustachian tube block secondary to adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx
  2. Allergy
  3. Unresolved otitis media
  4. Viral infections – adeno and rhinovirus

 

Symptoms

 

The disease affects children of 5–8 years of age. The symptoms include:

 

  1. Conductive hearing loss.
  2. Delayed and defective speech. Because of hearing loss, development of speech is delayed or defective.
  3. Mild earaches.

 

Otoscopic Findings

 

  •  Tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex, and may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

Audiometry

 

  •  Pure tone audiometry shows conduction hearing loss
  •  Tympanometry will show B type curve

 

Treatment

 

1. Medical

 

  • Decongestants.
  • Antihistamines or sometimes steroids may be used in cases of allergy.
  • Antibiotics. They are useful in cases of upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Middle Ear Aeration. Patients should repeatedly perform the Valsalva maneuver. Children can be given chewing gum to encourage repeated swallowing which opens the tube.

 

2. Surgical

 

  • Myringotomy and fluid aspiration
  • Grommet insertion
  • Tympanotomy and mastoidectomy
  • Surgical treatment of underlying causes like adenoid hypertrophy, tonsillar hypertrophy etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringitis bullosa involves the formation of blisters on the tympanic membrane due to inflammation, often associated with viral infections like influenza.

 

  • Symptoms: It is characterized by severe pain, occasionally hearing loss, and a rapid onset following an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The symptoms of prolonged hearing loss and the otoscopic findings of fluid levels visible in the image are not typical for myringitis bullosa, which usually presents with acute, painful blistering rather than effusion.

Option C. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, typically of rapid onset, involving signs of acute infection such as ear pain, fever, and general malaise.

 

  • Symptoms: The tympanic membrane often appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus and fluid, and the condition is usually accompanied by significant pain and fever.
  • Why Not: The child's symptoms described do not include acute infectious signs like significant pain or fever, and the duration of hearing loss suggests a more chronic condition.

Option D. Pneumo Tympanum refers to the presence of air in the middle ear space, which is not typically associated with fluid. It can occur due to trauma, barotrauma, or as a rare complication of severe nasal congestion.

 

  • Symptoms: This condition might present with a feeling of fullness or popping in the ear but not with the fluid level and air bubbles typically seen in fluid accumulation conditions.
  • Why Not: The presence of air bubbles alongside fluid specifically points towards fluid accumulation rather than just air, making pneumo tympanum less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media requires comprehensive management to prevent long-term effects on hearing and speech development. Early intervention, both medical and surgical, is essential for restoring normal ear function and preventing recurrent episodes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 84

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

 

  • Telomeres are short, TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. Telomeres do not contain any protein coding sequences. They are necessary for the complete replication of chromosome ends as well as the protection of the ends from fusion and degradation.
  • Telomeres at the ends of chromosomes are normally shortened with each cell division. Cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis may result if telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point. This is referred to as replicative senescence.
  • Telomerase is an enzyme that prevents telomeres from shortening. It is a specialized RNA-protein complex that adds nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes by using its own RNA as a template.
  • This enzyme is found in germ cells but not in most somatic cells. As a result, the majority of somatic cells age, their telomeres shorten, and they exit the cell cycle, rendering them unable to generate new cells to replace damaged cells.
  • In somatic cells, abnormal telomerase reactivation causes senescence and apoptosis. It allows the cells to divide more than usual.
  • Telomerase is usually reactivated in stem cells and cancer cells, and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: The following histological image is seen in the patient who is complaining of growth failure and abdominal distension.  Signs found were anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta-Glucocerebroside

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of cell which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. It is a sphingolipidoses and the most common lysosomal storage disease and occur due to deficiency of lysosomal enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase. The substrate glucosylceramide gets accumulated in macrophages causing eccentric nucleus.

Other clinical features are: Bony pain, pathological fracture, hepatosplenomegaly but no mental retardation (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease, characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and the presence of foam cells. Niemann-Pick disease often presents with mental retardation.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase: This enzyme has two forms, A and B. Deficiency of Hexosaminidase A leads to Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside, primarily affecting neurons. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, a cherry-red spot on the macula, and early death. Deficiency of both Hexosaminidase A and B leads to Sandhoff disease, which presents similarly to Tay-Sachs but with additional visceral involvement.

 

Option D. G-6-phosphatase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), characterized by impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Clinical features include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. Patients often present with a doll-like facies, protuberant abdomen, and growth retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

 

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option B. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option C. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass filling posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The above clinical scenario with recurrent spontaneous bleeding with unilateral nasal obstruction and contrast-enhanced CT showing a growth protruding into the nasopharynx, along with the Transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Epistaxis
  • Progressive nasal obstruction
  • Denasal speech
  • CHL
  • Broadening of nasal bridge
  • Proptosis leading to frog-face deformity
  • Involvement of cranial nerves – II, III, IV and VI

 

IOC is CECT – anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Millar sign)

 

Biopsy is avoided.

 

Treatment of choice – surgical approach

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antrochoanal Polyp: Typically arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, generally not as aggressive or vascular.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: A chronic granulomatous condition caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the nasal passages and respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Concha Bullosa: An aerated turbinate that usually does not present with bleeding or significant obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Prompt and accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is critical due to its potential for significant bleeding and local invasiveness. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, with preoperative planning crucial to manage the vascular nature of the tumor effectively.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) UNICEF

 

UNICEF

 

Applied Nutrition Program

 

  • UNICEF promoted the scheme by supplying basic equipment for production and training while FAO and WHO were involved in providing technical advice
  • UNICEF provided seeds, manure and water supply equipment for developing School gardens, to be utilized in school feeding programs

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CARE:  - ‘Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere’ supports following project:

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Option B. UNDP:  The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Option D. WHO:  World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: Which of the following has autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an individual needs to inherit two copies of the altered gene (one from each parent) to manifest the condition.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that having one copy of the altered gene is sufficient to express the condition.

 

Option B. Huntington’s disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern as well, where one copy of the altered gene is enough to cause the disease.

 

Option D. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: Familial Hypercholesterolemia is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but there are rare cases of autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AD (Autosomal Dominant)                                                                                       

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lactose Intolerance
  • Marfan Syndrome
  • Myotonic Dystrophy
  • AD Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • Porphyria Variegate

 

AR (Autosomal Recessive)

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
  • Sickle Cell disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Maple Syrup Urine disease
  • Homocystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Albinism
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Wilson's disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • AR Polycystic Kidney disease
  • Orotic Aciduria
  • Glycogen Storage Diseases
  • All Mucopolysaccharidosis (except Hunter’s)
  • All sphingolipidosis except Fabry’s disease

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 478

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis

 

Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: n Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C:06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D: Alopecia areata:

Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

 

For the management of Digoxin toxicity having the features of Bradycardia and a 3rd degree heart block, we need to administer Digibind, which is an antibody against Digoxin. It is also known as Digoxin immune Fab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lidocaine: Lidocaine is used to treat Ventricular Tachycardia or Ventricular Fibrillation.

 

Option C. DC cardioversion: DC cardioversion is used for tachyarrhythmias when pharmacologic treatment fails. It is not used in bradyarrhythmias.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic used for the treatment of GTCS. It can also be used as a class Ib antiarrhythmic drug for the treatment of Digoxin induced Ventricular Tachycardia, or any polymorphic ventricular tachycardia due to QT prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

 

Warburg metabolism is used by neoplastic cells to generate metabolic intermediates required for cell growth and multiplication.

 

Even when there is plenty of oxygen available, cancer cells shift their glucose metabolism away from the oxygen-hungry but efficient mitochondria and towards glycolysis. This phenomenon is known as the Warburg effect, and it is also referred to as aerobic glycolysis.

 

This metabolic change is so common in tumors that some consider it the eighth cancer hallmark.

 

Even though the latter produces more ATP, cancer cells prefer glycolysis (2 ATP) to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism. It's because pure oxidative phosphorylation generates a lot of ATP while also converting glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties to use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

 

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells: Incorrect. The Warburg effect actually increases glucose uptake and utilization by cancer cells to meet their high metabolic demands.

 

Option C. It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production: Incorrect. Glycolysis produces less ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation. The advantage of the Warburg effect lies in providing metabolic intermediates, not in ATP production.

 

Option D. It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal: Incorrect. While cancer cells do evade apoptosis and become immortal, this is not the direct reason they utilize the Warburg effect. The Warburg effect primarily supports cell growth and multiplication through the generation of biosynthetic precursors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neoplastic cells utilize the Warburg metabolism to generate metabolic intermediates necessary for cell growth and multiplication. Despite being less efficient in ATP production, glycolysis provides carbon moieties needed for biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, supporting rapid proliferation and cellular maintenance.

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option C. Maternal LH: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option D. Fetal GnRH: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of respiratory depression and is suspected of having overdosed on opioids. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

In a patient presenting with symptoms of respiratory depression suspected to be due to an opioid overdose, the immediate next step in management should be the administration of Naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression. It acts quickly and is typically administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or via nasal spray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naltrexone: While Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is used primarily for the long-term management of alcohol and opioid dependence, rather than for the acute reversal of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in the treatment of opioid dependence. It is not suitable for the immediate treatment of opioid overdose and its respiratory depressant effects.

 

Option D. Methadone: Methadone is a long-acting opioid used in the maintenance treatment of opioid dependence and chronic pain management. It is not used for the treatment of acute opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of suspected opioid overdose, particularly with signs of respiratory depression, the administration of Naloxone is the immediate and appropriate intervention. Naloxone acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) caused by red cell trauma. A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells. The same pressure gradients are also responsible for a mechanical heart sound on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenomegaly: Splenomegaly is often seen in various hemolytic anemias but is not specific for MAHA associated with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option B. Frontal bossing: Frontal bossing is seen in congenital hemolytic anemias such as thalassemia and sickle cell anemia due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, but not typically in MAHA.

 

Option D. Goitre: Goitre is related to thyroid disorders and is not associated with hemolytic anemia or mechanical heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of angiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

 

This enzyme is crucial in the final step of heme synthesis, where it inserts iron into protoporphyrin to form heme. In lead poisoning, ferrochelatase is inhibited, leading to decreased heme production, increased ALA production, and symptoms such as anemia, fatigue, and other neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: This enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase: Similar to Uroporphyrinogen III synthase, this enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option C. ALA synthase (Aminolevulinic acid synthase): It is a key enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway. Lead poisoning increase activity of ALA synthase. In lead poisoning, product inhibition by heme is  reduced leading to the accumulation of ALA and its precursor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:

 

  1. PBG synthase (another name ALA dehydratase)
  2. Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)

 

The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 306-307

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin. Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft: Botulinum toxin does not facilitate the release of noradrenaline. Its primary action is on the cholinergic neurons where it inhibits the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit nicotinic receptors. Instead, it prevents the release of acetylcholine, which means there is no neurotransmitter available to bind to and activate the nicotinic receptors.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors. In fact, it decreases neurotransmission by preventing the release of acetylcholine, which would otherwise stimulate these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.
