questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine: Incorrect. Segment I, particularly the initial part of the curve, typically represents the early filling phase of the bladder, not necessarily residual urine.

 

Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II: Incorrect. Segment II represents the continuation of the filling phase; micturition (urination) does not occur here because it typically begins when the bladder reaches its threshold capacity and the detrusor muscle contracts, which would be represented later in the graph.

 

Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred: Incorrect. The dotted line likely indicates phase transitions within the bladder's filling and voiding cycle, not necessarily the occurrence of micturition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segment II of a cystometrogram, characterized by Laplace's Law, illustrates how the bladder can accommodate increasing volumes of urine with minimal increase in pressure, showcasing the bladder's compliance during the urine storage phase. This is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions related to bladder storage and voiding dysfunction.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can occur in patients taking diuretics. Diuretics increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to its depletion. The triad of ECG changes associated with hypokalemia are distinctive and include:

 

  1. Flattening of T waves: This is often the earliest change observed in hypokalemia.
  2. Prominent U waves: These waves become more visible as the potassium levels drop further.
  3. ST depression: This can occur in more severe cases of hypokalemia.

 

These ECG changes are due to the altered repolarization of the heart muscle cells caused by low potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia, or high potassium levels, typically presents with different ECG changes, such as tall, peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, and possibly absent P waves. These findings are not consistent with the patient's ECG.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: While low magnesium can cause ECG changes and muscle weakness, the specific ECG findings in this case (flat T waves and prominent U waves) are more indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels do not typically cause specific ECG changes. Severe hypernatremia might cause cerebral edema and nonspecific T wave inversions, but it does not lead to the characteristic ECG findings seen with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is characterized by ECG changes such as flattened T waves, prominent U waves, and ST depression. It is commonly seen in patients on diuretics, and recognizing these ECG patterns is crucial for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

 

  • IgM assay cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin in stool samples.
  • C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism.
  • The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.
  • The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.
  • The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins - toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation.
  • The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.
  • Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin  A Or Toxin B or the organism in stool samples. The mere presence of bacteria in stool does not itend that the patient has the disease as clostridoides difficile is a commensal in the gut. Onlly confirmed toxin detection suggests significant infection with clostridoides difficile  This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 
  • Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment: This is true; fidaxomicin is a first-line treatment for C. difficile infection, especially in cases of recurrence.

 

Option B. It is toxin mediated: True; the clinical manifestations of CDI are due to the effects of toxins A and B.

 

Option D. Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris: Also true, this describes the characteristic appearance of the pseudomembrane seen in pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of CDI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: DNA packing is done by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histone

 

Histones are proteins responsible for DNA packaging. The DNA wraps around histones, forming a structure called a nucleosome. Histones are positively charged proteins that interact with the negatively charged DNA, allowing for efficient packaging and compaction of DNA strands. This packaging is essential for the organization of DNA within the cell nucleus and its regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein: Glycoproteins are not directly involved in DNA packaging. They are molecules composed of a protein and a carbohydrate moiety. While glycoproteins have various functions in the cell, they do not play a role in the compaction and organization of DNA.

 

Option C. Nucleic acid: DNA itself is a type of nucleic acid. DNA molecules are composed of nucleotides and serve as the genetic material of cells. DNA molecules do not package themselves; instead, they interact with histones and other proteins to undergo packaging and compaction.

 

Option D. Helicases: Helicases are enzymes responsible for unwinding and separating the DNA strands during processes such as DNA replication and transcription. They do not participate in DNA packaging; instead, their role is to facilitate the access of various cellular machinery to the DNA template.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins

 

Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO42- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to you with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal os

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of placenta previa which is caused due to placental implantation at the internal os.
  • Although the term placenta previa is diagnosed after 28 weeks, it can present with profuse bleeding at earlier gestational ages also.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: This will not present as profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks. This will present at a much earlier gestational age (6-8 weeks) and presents with abdominal pain (ruptured ectopic), vaginal bleeding (not profuse) and amenorrhoea (6-8 weeks)

 

Option C. Ovarian: Presents like an ectopic in the fallopian tube

 

Option D. Abdominal: This has varied presentations, but doesn’t present with profuse vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental implantation at the internal os, causing placenta previa, can lead to profuse vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 657, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atrial Septal Defect

 

According to the latest guidelines, there are specific indications for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis to prevent infection in high-risk patients. These indications include:

 

  1. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Patients with a history of infective endocarditis are at increased risk for recurrence and hence, are recommended for prophylaxis.
  2. Prosthetic Valves: Patients with prosthetic heart valves, especially mechanical valves, are susceptible to infections and require prophylaxis.
  3. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Those who have undergone cardiac transplant and have developed valvulopathy are also indicated for IE prophylaxis.
  4. Congenital Heart Disease: This includes any unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with prosthetic material for the first six months post-repair, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects.

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not listed among these high-risk conditions. ASD, especially without significant gradient across the atria or significant shunting, has a very low risk of causing infective endocarditis. Therefore, ASD does not fit into the current guidelines for IE prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Prior infective endocarditis significantly increases the risk of recurrent infection, thus requiring IE prophylaxis as per the guidelines.

 

Option C. Unrepaired Cyanotic Congenital Heart Disease: Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis, necessitating prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Patients who have undergone a cardiac transplant and have valvulopathy are at increased risk for infection and are indicated for IE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

 

Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET). In classic NETosis, the DNA is nuclear, not mitochondrial.

 

Some rare reports suggest that under certain non-lytic forms, mitochondrial DNA may be extruded, but this is not typical of NETs as understood in bacterial infections or sepsis.

 

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.

 

They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

 

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is detected in blood during sepsis:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are indeed detected in the blood during sepsis as part of the body's response to widespread infection.

 

Option B. It is produced in response to bacterial infection:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are produced in response to bacterial infection as well as fungal infections.

 

Option D. It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes:

 

  • True Statement: NETs consist of chromatin (DNA) along with antibacterial enzymes and peptides, which help in trapping and killing pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

Explanation

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autocrine: Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.

 

Option C. Endocrine: Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.

 

Option D. Merocrine: Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years
600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

 

For secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever, especially in patients without carditis or valvulitis, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines recommend administering benzathine penicillin G for either 5 years or until the patient is 21 years old, whichever is longer. Given that the child in this case is 11 years old, prophylaxis should continue until the child turns 21, resulting in a total duration of 10 years.

 

The dosage of benzathine penicillin G depends on the patient's weight:

 

  • For children weighing less than 27 kg, the dose is 600,000 IU.
  • For children weighing 27 kg or more, the dose is 1,200,000 IU.

 

Since the child weighs 26 kg, the appropriate dose is 600,000 IU. In high-risk areas such as India, the injection is administered every 3 weeks to ensure effective prophylaxis against recurrent streptococcal infections that could lead to rheumatic fever.

 

Note - Treatment duration options for a patient with valvulitis:

 

  • Standard Treatment Duration: Patients can be treated for a total duration of 10 years or until they reach the age of 40, whichever comes later. This approach is likely considered for cases where the valve damage is not extensively severe or life-threatening.
  • Severe Valve Damage: If there is severe damage to the valves, such as cases leading to or involving heart failure, lifelong therapy is recommended. This could include ongoing medication to manage the condition and potentially surgical interventions like valve replacement to address the mechanical deficits caused by the damage.

 

Note –

  • First-Line Therapy:
    • Injectable Penicillin: Typically administered once every 3 to 4 weeks.
    • Oral Alternative or if the patient prefers not to receive injections, Penicillin V can be used orally at a dose of 250 mg BD.
  • Second-Line Therapy (For patients with Penicillin Allergy): Sulfadiazine
  • Third-Line Therapy (For patients with both Penicillin and Sulfa Allergies): Macrolides (Either erythromycin or azithromycin, with erythromycin typically prescribed at 250 mg BD)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years: This option would be correct if the duration were 5 years, but since the patient must receive prophylaxis until age 21, this is insufficient.

 

Option C. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years: This dosage is for children weighing 27 kg or more. Since the child in this case weighs 26 kg, this dose is too high.

 

Option D. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life: Lifelong prophylaxis with this dosage is only indicated in patients with severe valvular damage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

This is Bitot’s spot shown in the picture due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B:

 

  • Function: Vitamin B is a group of vitamins that includes B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins play various roles in energy production, brain function, and cell metabolism
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Deficiencies in different B vitamins can result in a range of symptoms, including fatigue, neurological issues, anemia, and skin problems.

 

Option C. Vitamin C:

 

  • Function: Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, wound healing, and the absorption of iron from plant-based foods. It also acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: A lack of vitamin C can lead to scurvy, which includes symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and skin issues.

 

Option D. Vitamin K:

 

  • Function: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting and bone health. It helps in the synthesis of proteins involved in clot formation and bone mineralization.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin K deficiency can result in bleeding disorders and weakened bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 530

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

 

  • A 1-day-old neonate not passing urine since birth is a normal finding in neonates. Continuing breastfeeding and observation is the next step in management.
  • Delay in passing urine or stool is a cause for concern and requires investigation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Admit to NICU: This is not necessary as the absence of urination within the first 24 hours can be normal. Admission to NICU is reserved for cases where the neonate shows signs of distress or other serious conditions.

 

Option C. Start artificial feeding: This option is incorrect as breastfeeding should be continued unless there is a clear medical indication to switch to artificial feeding.

 

Option D. Start intravenous fluids: Starting IV fluids is not necessary unless the child shows signs of dehydration or is unable to take fluids orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

 

The clinical scenario of an unstable patient and the given X-ray findings, which showing hyperlucent right hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift is suggestive of a tension pneumothorax. Inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line followed by a chest tube in the triangle of safety is the best course of action for the management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Pericardiocentesis: This is performed in cases of cardiac tamponade (when presents with beck’s triad), where there is fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, not applicable here as the X-ray does not suggest this condition.

 

Option. B. Thoracotomy: Indicated for more complex chest injuries or when less invasive procedures fail to resolve the issue. It's a more invasive approach typically reserved for critical cases not resolved by needle thoracostomy or chest tube insertion.

 

Option. D. Chest tube insertion: While ultimately necessary for ongoing management and air evacuation, initial needle thoracostomy is critical to quickly relieve the pressure due to its speed and efficacy in an emergency setting. Chemical pleurodesis, which involves inhaling talc into the chest cavity, is used to achieve pleural adhesion.

questions.text: A 22y female is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Mild bleeding +. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

 

Explanation:

 

  • Repeat serum beta hCG after 48h:
    • The clinical scenario suggests a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), which could either be a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
    • The best next step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours. A rise in beta hCG by at least 66% would suggest a viable intrauterine pregnancy, while a plateau or drop would indicate a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is not the immediate next step in the management of a stable patient with PUL. It is reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of ectopic pregnancy with unstable vital signs or inconclusive non-invasive tests.

 

Option C. Repeat USG after 3 days: Repeating the ultrasound after 3 days may not provide additional useful information if the initial ultrasound did not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Monitoring beta hCG levels first is more informative and guides the need for further imaging.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: Simply waiting without further evaluation could delay diagnosis and appropriate management, especially in the case of a potential ectopic pregnancy, which can be life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), the next best step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

  • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • As per Williams Obstetrics:
    • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
    • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
    • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Additional 300kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.

 

Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.

 

Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Early-onset preeclampsia:
    • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
    • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
    • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
    • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
      • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
    • Biophysical Markers:
      • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
    • Biochemical Markers:
      • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
      • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
    • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
      • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.

 

Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like:
