    • Bilateral renal agenesis: Absence of both kidneys, leading to a lack of urine production, which is a major component of amniotic fluid.
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys: Kidneys that do not function properly, also leading to reduced urine output.
    • Bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder causes the kidneys to develop cysts, impairing their function.
    • Complex genito-urinary anomalies: Conditions like persistent cloaca and sirenomelia can affect kidney and urinary tract development, leading to oligohydramnios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula typically leads to polyhydramnios due to an obstruction to swallowing, resulting in an accumulation of amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Cardiac Abnormalities: Cardiac abnormalities usually lead to cardiac failure, which can result in fetal hydrops and polyhydramnios due to fluid accumulation in various fetal compartments.

 

Option D. Ureteral Stricture: Ureteral stricture will not lead to oligohydramnios unless there is bilateral involvement, which would be less common than the systemic impact of renal agenesis or other significant renal anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.

 

Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

 

Question is testing applied knowledge. Mentzer’s index needs to be calculated 

 

A peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells and a Mentzer index of less than 13 indicates thalassemia. As a result, HbA2 levels (which are elevated in thalassemia) must be tested next.

 

The Mentzer index, also known as the MCV/RBC count, can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). In both IDA and thalassemia, MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia but decreased in IDA. A lower RBC count in IDA indicates a smaller denominator, resulting in a higher MCV/RBC ratio.

 

Mentzer index is

 

  • More than 13 in iron-deficiency anemia
  • Less than 13 in thalassemia

 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival.

 

Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habits, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen.

 

Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ferritin levels: Relevant for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia but less specific for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Serum folate levels: Relevant for diagnosing macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency, not typically useful for microcytic anemia.

 

Option D. Serum homocysteine levels: Elevated in cases of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, related to macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

For a patient presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia and an RBC count suggesting thalassemia (Mentzer index < 13), the next best investigation is to measure HbA2 levels to confirm the diagnosis of beta-thalassemia.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

 

The laboratory findings indicate elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels while other liver enzymes are normal. This pattern is most consistent with obstructive jaundice.

 

In this condition, there is an obstruction in the bile ducts that prevents bile from being excreted into the intestine, leading to an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in conditions that involve cholestasis (impaired bile flow), which is characteristic of obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: This type of jaundice is caused by the excessive breakdown of red blood cells, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin. Alkaline phosphatase levels remain normal in hemolytic jaundice.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice: Hepatic jaundice occurs due to liver cell damage, which impairs the liver's ability to process and excrete bilirubin. This condition typically shows elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), not just alkaline phosphatase.

 

Option D. Prehepatic jaundice: This term is often used interchangeably with hemolytic jaundice, where the problem lies before the bilirubin reaches the liver. Elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in prehepatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note – Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion are characteristic of mucormycosis, a serious fungal infection commonly seen in diabetic patients and other immunocompromised individuals. Amphotericin B is the preferred initial treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad antifungal coverage and effectiveness against Mucorales, the group of fungi responsible for this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily for Candida and Cryptococcus infections. It is not effective against Mucorales and therefore not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is another antifungal agent with a broad spectrum of action but has limited use due to its side effects and is not effective against Mucorales, making it inappropriate for mucormycosis treatment.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea infections) and is not effective against Mucorales. It is not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) levonorgesterel IUD

 

Explanation:

 

  • Suitable during lactation
    • LNG-IUS is a progestin-only method
    • Does not reduce milk production (unlike estrogen-containing pills)
  • Controls heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • LNG-IUS reduces menstrual blood loss by 70–90%
    • Improves hemoglobin levels and quality of life
  • Long-acting and reversible
    • Provides effective contraception for up to 5 years
    • Fertility returns quickly after removal
  • Low maintenance
    • No daily action required
    • Ideal for busy mothers with young children
  • High efficacy
    • Failure rate <0.2% per year
    • One of the most effective reversible methods
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
    • Category 1 (no restriction) after 6 weeks postpartum
    • Safe for breastfeeding women
  • Fewer systemic side effects
    • Hormone acts locally in the uterus
    • Minimal systemic absorption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Mala N: Mala N is also a possible contraceptive in this situation. There is high chance of non compliance and missed pill. LNG IUS is better option in such cases

 

Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection: Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. it may lead to delay in return to menses, and also requires follow up every 3 months for next dose, which is inconvenient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the urologist with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Upon examination, the physician noted tenderness in the lower abdomen and a palpable mass in the right flank area. Further evaluation revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction

 

The clinical scenario and the imaging indicate a likely diagnosis of pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition where there is a blockage at the point where the renal pelvis meets the ureter.
  • This blockage can lead to hydronephrosis, which is the swelling of a kidney due to a buildup of urine.
  • PUJ obstruction can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Symptoms can include flank pain, recurrent UTIs, and a palpable mass in severe cases.
  • The findings from imaging studies, showing hydronephrosis (dilated pelvicalyceal system), would support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Putty kidney: A putty kidney refers to a kidney that has been extensively damaged by tuberculosis. The kidney appears pale, and is often shrunk, firm, and non-functional. It would not typically cause a palpable mass and recurrent UTIs in the described manner of the patient in the question.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: Staghorn calculi are large kidney stones that occupy a large portion of the renal pelvis and its calyces, often having a shape resembling a stag's horn. They can lead to recurrent UTIs and can sometimes be palpable, especially if the kidney is also enlarged due to obstruction. However, the description in the question and the image seems more indicative of an obstruction at the PUJ rather than a staghorn calculus.

 

Option D. Cystic kidney: A cystic kidney, as the name suggests, is characterized by multiple cysts in the kidney. There are several diseases, like polycystic kidney disease, that can lead to cyst formation in kidneys. These cysts can sometimes cause pain, enlarged kidneys, and in some cases, recurrent UTIs. However, the specific findings from the imaging study mentioned in the question don't necessarily align with a simple cystic kidney diagnosis.

 

Given the findings mentioned in the question, a palpable mass in the right flank area, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and imaging results, Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option A) is the most consistent and likely diagnosis for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition causing blockage where the renal pelvis meets the ureter, leading to hydronephrosis and symptoms like flank pain and recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging typically shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1 receptors 

 

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that primarily acts as a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist. By antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to diuresis or increased urine output. Adenosine normally promotes water reabsorption in the renal tubules, and its blockade by theophylline results in increased urine production. This mechanism is separate from its therapeutic action in COPD, which involves bronchodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-10: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It is not a direct target of theophylline. IL-10 plays a role in regulating immune responses, but it is not involved in the diuretic effect or the primary action of theophylline in COPD treatment.

 

Option B. Histone Deacetylase: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is an enzyme involved in chromatin remodelling and gene expression regulation. While theophylline has been suggested to have some modulatory effects on HDAC, especially in the context of COPD and asthma, it is not the mechanism responsible for the increased urine output observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Beta 2 Adrenergic Receptors: While theophylline has mild bronchodilatory effects thought to be mediated through inhibition of phosphodiesterase (increasing cAMP levels in smooth muscle), leading to relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, beta 2 adrenergic receptors are more specifically targeted by drugs like salbutamol. Theophylline's diuretic effect is not mediated through beta 2 adrenergic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PET CT

 

The above imaging modality is a PET CT scan.

 

  • PET scan: Positron emission tomography
  • 18-FDG: 18F is combined with deoxy glucose (ligand)
  • To look for malignant cells
  • Functional metabolism

 

Warburg Effect: Malignant cells → anaerobic glycolysis

 

 

  • Concept: Coincidence – Annihilation reaction
  • Prerequisite before performing PET scan: Blood glucose measurement

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Cerebral blood flow scan: Typically involves methods like SPECT or perfusion MRI to measure blood flow in the brain.

 

 

Option. C. Sestamibi scan: Generally used for myocardial perfusion imaging or parathyroid imaging, involving a different radiotracer.

 

 

Option. D. Full body MDCT (Multi-detector computed tomography): Provides high-resolution anatomical information across the whole body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A PET CT scan is crucial for the integrated assessment of anatomical and metabolic information, particularly useful in oncology for identifying and tracking the behavior of tumors based on their glucose metabolism, as visualized through radiotracer uptake.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months: This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.

 

Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year: While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.

 

Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years: This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

The positive HLA-DQ2 and the presentation of diarrhea and weight loss in a child suggest the possibility of celiac disease. Therefore, the child should be advised to follow a gluten-free diet.

 

Celiac disease is a condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. This immune response leads to damage to the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients, which can result in diarrhea, weight loss, and other symptoms.

 

HLA-DQ2 is a genetic marker that is present in over 90% of individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, a positive test for HLA-DQ2 can suggest the possibility of celiac disease, although a definitive diagnosis requires further testing, such as serologic testing and intestinal biopsy.

 

The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin, a gluten-derived peptide. In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by an intestinal enzyme called tissue transglutaminase (tTG), resulting in a more immunogenic form of the protein that is presented to helper T cells. This leads to mucosal inflammation, tissue damage, and other symptoms.

 

Children with celiac disease typically present with diarrhea, weight loss, and growth failure. Other symptoms may include malabsorption, bloating, irregular bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis, ataxia, and abnormal liver enzymes. Screening for celiac disease is performed by testing for serum antibodies, including tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deaminated anti-gliadin antibodies. The diagnosis is confirmed in patients with positive antibodies by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Microscopic examination of the biopsy sample reveals intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not relevant to the management of celiac disease. Fat intake is not directly related to the immune response triggered by gluten.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While some individuals with celiac disease may temporarily develop lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage, a lactose-free diet is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: This diet is not related to the management of celiac disease. The primary issue is the immune response to gluten, not carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presented to you with hypotension. An ECG was done, which showed wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IV NaHCO3

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, which includes hypotension, wide QRS complexes, and right axis deviation on the ECG. TCAs can block sodium channels in the heart, leading to QRS widening and the potential for serious arrhythmias. They also have anticholinergic effects, which can contribute to the clinical picture.

 

The first-line treatment for TCA overdose, especially in the presence of cardiac toxicity such as wide QRS complexes, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3). Sodium bicarbonate works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to overcome the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs. It also increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which can help stabilize cardiac cell membranes and improve conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antiarrhythmics: While antiarrhythmics might be considered in other cases of cardiac arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for TCA overdose. In fact, some antiarrhythmic drugs can worsen the condition by further blocking sodium channels or prolonging the QT interval.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure and certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not indicated for the treatment of TCA toxicity and can potentially exacerbate hypotension and cardiac conduction abnormalities.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant that can also be used for certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not effective in treating the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs and is not recommended for managing TCA overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for tricyclic antidepressant overdose, especially when presenting with wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3).

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

In a patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the immediate management involves FLIP Therapy (fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy and Potassium management). This patient's blood glucose is significantly elevated, and the presence of ketones indicates DKA, which is a medical emergency.

 

1. Fluids: The initial step is to administer intravenous (IV) fluids to correct dehydration and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. The typical approach involves giving isotonic saline (0.9% sodium chloride) at a rate of 10-20 mL/kg/hr (2-3L) for the first 2-3 hours. This helps to correct hypovolemia, improve perfusion, and begin to lower blood glucose levels.

 

Criteria for fluid management: After the initial two to three hours of treatment, switch from initial fluids (typically normal saline) to half normal saline for ongoing maintenance. If capillary blood glucose (CBG) drops below 300 mg/dL, and specifically if it falls below 250 mg/dL, add 5% dextrose water to the regimen. The purpose of adding dextrose is to maintain a target CBG range of 200 to 300 mg/dL. This range helps prevent hypoglycemia, which is a critical concern in the management process.

 

2. Insulin: Insulin therapy is crucial to halt ketogenesis and reduce blood glucose levels. After 1 hr of fluid start insulin. The recommended protocol for DKA involves IV regular insulin because of its rapid onset and short duration of action. The insulin regimen follows a fixed dose insulin infusion (FDII) approach. This helps to normalize blood glucose and ketone levels efficiently.

 

First option: Continuous infusion at 0.15 units/kg/hour.

 

Second option (more commonly used): Administer a 0.1 units/kg bolus, followed by a 0.1 units/kg/hour infusion.

 

IV regular insulin is preferred over subcutaneous (SC) insulin in emergency settings like DKA due to its predictable absorption and ability to be titrated easily based on frequent blood glucose monitoring.

 

Adjustments Based on Blood Glucose Levels: Monitor capillary blood glucose (CBG). If CBG drops below 300 mg/dL, reduce the insulin infusion to half the dose (0.05 units/kg/hour).

 

Criteria for Stopping Insulin Infusion: Insulin infusion can be stopped ONLY when the patient tolerates oral feeds without vomiting or abdominal pain. Other criteria include resolution of ketoacidosis, negative or trace positive plasma ketones, and an anion gap less than 12, pH more than 7.3 and serum bicarbonate more than 18. Transition to subcutaneous insulin upon meeting these criteria.

 

Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab
 

Alirocumab and Evolocumab are PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors. These works by inhibiting the PCSK9 enzyme which is responsible for degradation of LDL receptors in the liver. Therefore, these drugs lead to an increased number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on liver cells and a subsequent decrease in LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. PCSK9 inhibitors are used for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease and have not adequately responded to statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, which leads to a reduction in the total amount of cholesterol presented to the liver. It does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Option C. Bempedoic Acid: Bempedoic acid is a relatively new cholesterol-lowering medication. It inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, but it is not a PCSK9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Clofibrate: Clofibrate is a fibrate used to lower lipid levels, particularly triglycerides. It works by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient receiving anti-tubercular treatment complains of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs. He is not diabetic and drinks alcohol on occasion. Which of the following vitamins should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The patient's symptoms of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs, in the context of receiving anti-tubercular treatment, are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. One of the mainstays of tuberculosis (TB) treatment includes the drug isoniazid, which is known to cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Supplementing with vitamin B6 can prevent or alleviate these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with anti-tubercular therapy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more commonly linked to conditions like pernicious anemia or dietary deficiencies.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can lead to various symptoms, including skin disorders and anemia, but it is not specifically linked to the type of neuropathy seen in patients taking isoniazid for TB.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Deficiency of vitamin B3 leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and is not associated with the peripheral neuropathy observed in patients on isoniazid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients receiving isoniazid as part of anti-tubercular therapy should be supplemented with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy, a common side effect of this medication.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a common and serious complication in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites. It is diagnosed when the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3. In this case, the neutrophil count is significantly higher than the threshold, indicating a strong likelihood of SBP.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Liver Disease Symptoms: The patient presents with symptoms typical of chronic liver disease, including abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis.
  • Neutrophil Count: An ascitic fluid neutrophil count > 250 cells/mm3 is diagnostic of SBP. This patient's count of > 650 cells/mm3 strongly supports this diagnosis.
  • Management: Immediate antibiotic therapy is crucial for SBP. Standard treatment involves third-generation cephalosporins like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone. In areas with high resistance to these antibiotics, piperacillin-tazobactam used in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant Ascites: Malignant ascites is associated with peritoneal carcinomatosis or other cancers. The neutrophil count in ascitic fluid in such cases is generally lower, and the fluid is often exudative rather than the neutrophil-predominant fluid seen in SBP.

 

Option C. Tubercular Ascites: Tubercular ascites usually presents with a lymphocyte-predominant fluid rather than neutrophil-predominant. It is also associated with other findings such as a high protein content and a positive acid-fast bacilli smear.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: Intestinal obstruction may lead to ascites, but the fluid analysis would not typically show a high neutrophil count. The clinical presentation and history would also differ significantly, focusing more on obstructive symptoms like severe pain, vomiting, and constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be suspected in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites if the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3, necessitating prompt antibiotic treatment.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh
Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers
No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area
Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text: A patient presents with an BT leprosy lesion on the face as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facial Nerve

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests a case of leprosy, with the facial nerve being the most commonly affected cranial nerve.

 

  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which impacts the mucous membranes, cutaneous tissues, and peripheral nerves leading to sensory and motor deficits.

 

Most commonly affected nerves:

 

  • Peripheral nerves: Ulnar > Posterior tibial nerve, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • Cranial nerves: Facial nerve > Trigeminal nerve.
  • Notably, facial skin lesions are associated with a 10-fold increase in the risk of facial nerve involvement in leprosy cases.
  • Facial nerve involvement can lead to facial muscle weakness, paralysis, and loss of facial expressions, which are characteristic features of this condition.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) primarily innervates the face and is responsible for sensations such as touch and pain.
  • While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the most commonly involved nerve in BT leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve:

 

  • The abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
  • In leprosy, it is less commonly involved compared to the facial nerve, especially in BT leprosy.

 

Option D. Optic nerve:

 

The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and is not commonly affected in leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve (option A).

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 28, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A Mediterranean person receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMP pathway

 

This is the correct pathway affected by G6PD enzyme deficiency. G6PD is an enzyme crucial for the proper functioning of the HMP pathway. Deficiency in G6PD can lead to hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) in response to oxidative stress, as the HMP pathway is responsible for generating reducing equivalents (NADPH) necessary to protect cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the HMP pathway, not glycolysis. Glycolysis is a separate metabolic pathway involved in the breakdown of glucose for energy production.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway responsible for producing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, and it does not rely on the G6PD enzyme.

 

Option D. Krebs cycle: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). The Krebs cycle is involved in the oxidative metabolism of acetyl-CoA, and G6PD deficiency primarily impacts the earlier steps of glucose metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.

 

Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 182

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • In the context of penetrating trauma, especially with evisceration (protrusion of internal tissues or organs through a wound), an emergency laparotomy becomes the procedure of choice to address any potential life-threatening injuries, stop bleeding, and repair damaged structures.
  • Evisceration is an indicator of full-thickness injury to the abdominal wall and potential underlying organ damage.

 

Indications for emergency laparotomy in penetrating trauma include:

 

  • Unstable patient
  • Features of peritonitis
  • Evisceration
  • Gunshot wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone in this scenario would delay necessary intervention and could worsen the patient's outcome. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to manage the evisceration and associated internal injuries.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydration: While IV hydration might be a part of the supportive care for a trauma patient, it is not the primary treatment for an evisceration injury. The priority would be to address the traumatic injury directly through surgery.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach, like observation, is passive and is not suitable for traumatic injuries that are obviously severe, like evisceration. Delay in surgical intervention could lead to complications and worsen the patient's prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance, and hand and foot enlargement. What is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pegvisomant

 

The patient's symptoms suggest acromegaly, a condition characterized by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It blocks the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, leading to decreased levels of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the acromegaly symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue, which can be used in the treatment of acromegaly. It works by inhibiting the release of growth hormone from the pituitary gland. However, it is not a growth hormone receptor antagonist; instead, it reduces GH secretion.

 

Option C. Cabergoline: Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist primarily used in the treatment of prolactinomas, another type of pituitary adenoma. It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for acromegaly and does not act as a growth hormone receptor antagonist.

 

Option D. Olcegepant: Olcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist used in the research for migraine treatment. It is not used in the treatment of acromegaly or related to growth hormone activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, thereby reducing the symptoms associated with elevated growth hormone levels.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

 

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

 

Other marked structures:

 

  • 1- Optic nerve
  • 2- Abducent nerve
  • 4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve (II): The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm. At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over.  Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

 

Option B. Abducent Nerve (VI): This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally). It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit. Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy. This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

 

Option D. Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance). It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trigeminal Nerve (V) is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing). 

 

It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).

 

The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets. 

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine

 

Carnitine plays a crucial role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane for subsequent beta-oxidation. It forms a complex with fatty acids, allowing them to enter the mitochondria.

 

Fatty acid transport into mitochondria from cytoplasm involve the carnitine shuttle system using enzymes Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) and CPT-II. CPT-I is RLE of fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation of fatty acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyl carrier protein: Acyl carrier proteins are involved in fatty acid synthesis rather than transport across the mitochondrial membrane. They are essential components of fatty acid biosynthesis pathways.

 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: Cholesterol transporters primarily facilitate the transport of cholesterol, not fatty acids, across cellular membranes. They are not directly involved in fatty acid transport into mitochondria.

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT is an enzyme responsible for esterifying cholesterol, and it does not play a role in fatty acid transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.

 

Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:
