MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

 

The question clearly indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning (elevated blood levels and associated clinical features)

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of multiple enzymes involved in heme synthesis pathway, of which main inhibited enzymes are:

 

  • ALAD (Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase)- Mnemonic ALAD sounds like lead
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • Ferrochelatase

 

This leads to increased levels of multiple precursors of Heme production like:

 

  • Protoporphyrin
  • Coproporphyrin
  • δ-amino levulinic acid

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III: Not directly inhibited by lead. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen I: Not directly involved in lead poisoning. Uroporphyrinogen I is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway but not specifically inhibited by lead.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Not involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This enzyme is part of the metabolic pathway converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

 

The patient's presentation and findings are indicative of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump effectively. This condition can result from various causes, including pericarditis, malignancy, trauma, or post-myocardial infarction.

 

Key features supporting cardiac tamponade:

 

  1. Chest pain and dyspnea: These symptoms can worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, a condition known as orthopnea.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Due to the fluid in the pericardial sac, the heart sounds are dampened.
  3. Clear lungs: This helps differentiate from pulmonary causes of dyspnea.
  4. Enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR: The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, indicative of pericardial effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Pulmonary edema: This condition typically presents with bilateral crackles on lung auscultation and possibly a history of heart failure. The chest X-ray would show features like Kerley B lines, pleural effusions, or alveolar edema, which are absent in this case.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary embolism: This can present with dyspnea and chest pain, but the ECG findings and clear lung fields on auscultation are less supportive. Additionally, acute pulmonary embolism typically does not cause an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

 

Option C. Acute MI (Myocardial Infarction): While acute MI can present with chest pain and dyspnea, it usually does not result in muffled heart sounds or an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Acute MI would more likely present with changes on ECG and possibly signs of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

 

This is the correct answer. McArdle's Disease results from a deficiency of myophosphorylase, which is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within muscle cells. The lack of myophosphorylase impairs the ability of muscle cells to release glucose from glycogen during physical activity, leading to muscle fatigue, pain, and other symptoms typically observed in McArdle's Disease patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism in the liver, not in muscle cells. Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase lead to other types of Glycogen Storage Diseases, such as Von Gierke's Disease (GSD Ia).

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase : While this enzyme plays a role in glycogen metabolism, it is not the enzyme affected in McArdle's Disease. Instead, it is myophosphorylase that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the initial steps of glucose metabolism but is not directly related to glycogen breakdown or McArdle's Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 167

choices.text: Examination in chief

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading questions are not allowed in all of the following except? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross examination

 

In Cross examination, leading questions are allowed to challenge the witness's testimony and credibility.

 

Leading Question:

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by lawyer, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Re-examination: Follow-up questioning by the party who called the witness, after cross-examination. In this leading questions are not allowed to ensure the witness's own account is clarified or points raised during cross-examination are rebutted without leading the witness.

 

Option C. Examination in Chief: The initial questioning of a witness by the party who called them. Leading questions are not permitted to ensure the witness's testimony is their own and not influenced by the questioner.

 

Option D. Dying Declaration: A statement made by a person who believes they are about to die, concerning the cause or circumstances of their death. Leading questions are not allowed to ensure the statement is voluntary and not influenced, preserving its reliability.

 

Educational Objective

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in:

 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in:

 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief
